comments.text:
User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1) AppleWebKit/534.30 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/12.0.742.100 Safari/534.30
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.1; de; rv:1.9.2.18) Gecko/20110616 Thunderbird/3.1.11

The CA "InstantSSL" offers a widely used free S/MIME-certificate service, which signs certificates using the "E" attribute only.

E = [email-address]

While Microsoft shows the certificate's name as [email-address], Mozilla products identify these certificates as a weird internal name, which is "le-[some UUID]", e.g. le-00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000 .

As this certificate has a valid "E" attribute, I don't see any reason why the certificate shouldn't have this attribute as name, even if "CN" is missing. When you have multiple email accounts and your CA isn't issuing a CN, it is very hard to find the correct certificate when every certificate has the name "le-[some UUID]".

I hope that you can accept my request and handle the certificate name-display like Microsoft does.

Reproducible: Always

comments.text:
Additional information: I just found out that StartSSL, which is under the Top10 of the certificate issuers, issues also S/MIME certificates without CN. The attributes are:

E = [email address]
Description = [random token]

This makes this issue a bit more important.

*Note: In the old version of StartCom's issuing system, the attributes were

E = [email address]
CN = StartCom Free Certificate Member
O = Persona Not Validated
Description = [random token]

They have probably removed O and CN since it showed in Windows multiple entries "StartCom Free Certificate Member" for different email-accounts.
